title: How to Make a Tostada

steps.headline: Dry the tortillas in your oven for 10 minutes at 250 °F (121 °C).
steps.description: Preheat your oven to 250 °F (121 °C), and spread the corn tortillas evenly on a baking pan. Set the tortillas on the center rack for 10 minutes so they’ll fry better. You can lay the tortillas directly on the oven rack if you want. Just be sure they won’t slip through the grates.Tip: You can make your own corn tortillas with masa harina flour if you want your tostada to be homemade.

steps.headline: Heat a small pan with ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) of vegetable oil.
steps.description: Put a small frying pan over medium-high heat, and fill it so you have a shallow layer of cooking oil. Heat the oil until it’s  sizzling hot, but not so it’s smoking. You can use any light cooking oil, such as canola or peanut oil, when you fry your tortillas. Keep a fire extinguisher nearby in case of an oil fire.

steps.headline: Fry the tortillas for 30 seconds per side.
steps.description: Put 1 tortilla in the oil at a time. Push the tortilla down into the oil with a pair of tongs so it’s completely submerged. After about 30 seconds, flip the tortilla over and cook it for an additional 30 seconds or until it’s golden brown. Repeat the frying process for each of your tortillas. You may need to heat up more oil over time after some of it cooks off. Make sure the oil is sizzling hot again before putting in another tortilla.

steps.headline: Shake the tortillas and set them on paper towels to absorb any excess oil.
steps.description: Lift the tortillas out of the oil and give them a light shake so the oil can drip off of them. Set the tortillas on a layer of paper towels and lightly pat them dry. You can either spread the tortillas out or stack them on top of one another. Don’t press too hard on the tortillas while you’re drying them or else you could break them.

steps.headline: Spread 2 ⁄2 oz (71 g) of refried beans on each tortilla.
steps.description: Scoop out a small amount of heated refried beans and spread it over each of your tortillas. Adding a layer of refried beans first helps your other toppings stay in place. You can use store-bought refried beans or make your own.

steps.headline: Sprinkle cheese on top of the beans so it can melt.
steps.description:
Spread 1 ⁄2 ounces (43 g) of shredded cheese over each of your tostadas. The heat from the beans will help melt the cheese so it has a gooey consistency. Save some of the cheese if you want to sprinkle more on top once you’re finished adding toppings. Popular Cheeses to Use
• Monterrey Jack• Cheddar• Queso fresco

steps.headline: Put on your choice of cooked meat for added protein.
steps.description: Since tostadas are basically flat tacos, you can put in whatever meat you would normally have. Try different meats, such as ground beef, chicken, fish, or steak, for different flavored tostadas. Make sure your meat is fully cooked before putting it on your tostada. You don’t have to add meat if you’re a vegetarian. Instead, you can use more refried beans or tofu.

steps.headline: Use diced tomatoes, avocado, and shredded lettuce for fresh flavors.
steps.description: Cut some fresh vegetables to put on top of your tostadas. Tomatoes, avocado, and shredded lettuce all help add different textures and flavors to your meal. Experiment with different vegetable combinations to see what you prefer. If you don’t want to slice fresh avocados, you can use guacamole instead. Don’t add too many toppings, or else it may be difficult to eat your tostada without it breaking.

steps.headline: Add salsa or jalapenos for a spicy kick.
steps.description: Chop fresh jalapenos and place on top of your tostadas. For more spice, spread a spoonful of medium or hot salsa over each tostada. Use a dollop of sour cream on top if you want to cut back on some of the spiciness.

text:
Frying the Tortillas Dry the tortillas in your oven for 10 minutes at 250 °F (121 °C). Preheat your oven to 250 °F (121 °C), and spread the corn tortillas evenly on a baking pan. Set the tortillas on the center rack for 10 minutes so they’ll fry better. You can lay the tortillas directly on the oven rack if you want. Just be sure they won’t slip through the grates.Tip: You can make your own corn tortillas with masa harina flour if you want your tostada to be homemade. Heat a small pan with ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) of vegetable oil. Put a small frying pan over medium-high heat, and fill it so you have a shallow layer of cooking oil. Heat the oil until it’s  sizzling hot, but not so it’s smoking. You can use any light cooking oil, such as canola or peanut oil, when you fry your tortillas. Keep a fire extinguisher nearby in case of an oil fire. Fry the tortillas for 30 seconds per side. Put 1 tortilla in the oil at a time. Push the tortilla down into the oil with a pair of tongs so it’s completely submerged. After about 30 seconds, flip the tortilla over and cook it for an additional 30 seconds or until it’s golden brown. Repeat the frying process for each of your tortillas. You may need to heat up more oil over time after some of it cooks off. Make sure the oil is sizzling hot again before putting in another tortilla. Shake the tortillas and set them on paper towels to absorb any excess oil. Lift the tortillas out of the oil and give them a light shake so the oil can drip off of them. Set the tortillas on a layer of paper towels and lightly pat them dry. You can either spread the tortillas out or stack them on top of one another. Don’t press too hard on the tortillas while you’re drying them or else you could break them. Adding Toppings Spread 2 ⁄2 oz (71 g) of refried beans on each tortilla. Scoop out a small amount of heated refried beans and spread it over each of your tortillas. Adding a layer of refried beans first helps your other toppings stay in place. You can use store-bought refried beans or make your own. Sprinkle cheese on top of the beans so it can melt. Spread 1 ⁄2 ounces (43 g) of shredded cheese over each of your tostadas. The heat from the beans will help melt the cheese so it has a gooey consistency. Save some of the cheese if you want to sprinkle more on top once you’re finished adding toppings. Popular Cheeses to Use
• Monterrey Jack• Cheddar• Queso fresco Put on your choice of cooked meat for added protein. Since tostadas are basically flat tacos, you can put in whatever meat you would normally have. Try different meats, such as ground beef, chicken, fish, or steak, for different flavored tostadas. Make sure your meat is fully cooked before putting it on your tostada. You don’t have to add meat if you’re a vegetarian. Instead, you can use more refried beans or tofu. Use diced tomatoes, avocado, and shredded lettuce for fresh flavors. Cut some fresh vegetables to put on top of your tostadas. Tomatoes, avocado, and shredded lettuce all help add different textures and flavors to your meal. Experiment with different vegetable combinations to see what you prefer. If you don’t want to slice fresh avocados, you can use guacamole instead. Don’t add too many toppings, or else it may be difficult to eat your tostada without it breaking. Add salsa or jalapenos for a spicy kick. Chop fresh jalapenos and place on top of your tostadas. For more spice, spread a spoonful of medium or hot salsa over each tostada. Use a dollop of sour cream on top if you want to cut back on some of the spiciness.
